results.title: John Miles: drafted Vietnam
results.brief_description: John Miles recalls the 29th of September 1965 as the date that he commenced his National Service. While he was away, the political climate changed dramatically in Australia. Miles remembers his experience of the Vietnam War and his struggles once home in Australia. Miles’ treatment on return to Australia initially made left him feeling bitter, but a trip back to Vietnam was crucial to his personal transformation and healing.
results.description: John Miles recalls the 29th of September 1965 as the date that he commenced his National Service. While he was away, the political climate changed dramatically in Australia. results.title: An interview with Cyril Sayles
results.brief_description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.

Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.

results.title: Interview with Ben Whitham
results.brief_description: In war, you are discouraged from keeping records or taking photographs. However, soldiers broke those rules in order to help remember. Born on a small soldier’s settlement farm, Ben Witham grew up hearing stories about the war. Having a father who served in Gallipoli, to his own service in World War II, Witham recalls the camaraderie and the lighter side of war. He emphasises the bonds of fellow servicemen and the celebration of this during commemorations for ANZACs.

results.title: Every man for himself
results.creator_credit: Arthur Bedford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Hiding from the Germans amongst olive trees in Greece, Arthur Bedford and his fellow soldiers were told to get out. “Every man for himself”. Not only did they manage to escape, they managed to fend off a enemy bombing attack and didn’t suffer a single casualty.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arthur Bedford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Boy called "Rabbit"
results.creator_credit: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Cumming’s dearest memory of the time he served in Vietnam was a young boy by the name of “Rabbit”. While “Rabbit” couldn’t speak English, he was popular with the Australian soldiers for his fast running and bravery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Big blip, small blip
results.creator_credit: Knox McKenzie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Trained as a radar operator, Knox McKenzie saw himself posted around Australia throughout World War II, and eventually on Melville Island. It was an isolating job, waiting for signal “blips” to pick up planes coming in. A big blip was a friend and a small blip was a foe. McKenzie’s innate independance helped him to see the entire experience as an education and one to remember for the rest of his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Knox McKenzie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

It was an isolating job, waiting for signal “blips” to pick up planes coming in. A big blip was a friend and a small blip was a foe. McKenzie’s innate independance helped him to see the entire experience as an education and one to remember for the rest of his life.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [Morwell veterans]
results.brief_description: Ten Victorian veterans from Morwell tell stories of their time of service, providing their unique perspectives on army life, wartime and coming home to Australia. Produced with the assistance of Morwell RSL and the students of Kurnai College, Morwell.
results.title_for_label: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [Morwell veterans]

results.title: Tour of duty
results.creator_credit: Paul Rayment, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While he saw it as his duty to defend his country against communism, it wasn’t until Paul Rayment went to Vietnam that he realised how lucky Australia really was. However, on his return, Rayment became estranged from his community and friends, and it took a while to rebuild those ties and his connection to the country he had earlier set out to defend.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Rayment, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.brief_description: When World War II broke out, some men would do anything to sign up and when the war was over, most men would do anything for a beer. Steve Whelan came from a family of servicemen and was eager to do his bit. He tells the story of how he and a group of fellow prisoners of war found a way to escape and find a beer.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Steve Whelan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Sink or swim
results.creator_credit: Gwynneth Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Gwynneth Cole joined the army in 1944, roles for women were limited. While Cole didn’t get to serve on the front line, she was posted to different bases in Australia as a nurse and faced many hardships and the realities of war. Cole greatly values her time in the army and reflects on the opportunities for women and the independent streak she has passed on to her four daughters.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gwynneth Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
